conclusion: Analyze the situation using optics principles, specifically Snell's Law and total internal reflection.
A beam of light is incident from air onto a transparent medium sphere at point A, with incident angle i.
The center of the sphere is point O.
Light bends towards the normal due to refraction when entering a transparent medium from air.
Snell's Law: n1 sin(i) = n2 sin(r), where n1 is refractive index of air, n2 is refractive index of sphere, i is angle of incidence, r is angle of refraction.
As incident angle i increases, angle of refraction r also increases, causing light to bend more towards the sphere's surface.
Total internal reflection occurs when light travels from a medium with higher refractive index to lower refractive index and angle of incidence exceeds critical angle.
Critical angle θc calculated using: θc = arcsin(n2/n1).
For total internal reflection, angle of incidence inside sphere must be greater than critical angle.
As i becomes large, angle of refraction r approaches 90 degrees, light travels almost parallel to surface inside sphere.
If incident angle i is large enough, angle of incidence inside sphere when light tries to exit will exceed critical angle.
Light will be totally reflected inside the sphere.
Final answer: Yes, when incident angle i is large enough, light will be totally reflected when emitted from inside the sphere.
